metadata.synopsis: Minsc's default dialogue. In the current entries, he reflects on his opinion of us and our adventures so far, as well as revealing a little of history.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: You called yourself 'nydeshka' before. What does that mean?

393.speaker: Minsc
393.text: It is a phrase in the old tongue of Rashemen - meaning 'blunt blade'.

274.speaker: Minsc
274.text: Even in the very belly of their battle-rage, a berserker must always know friend from foe.

321.speaker: Minsc
321.text: The berserker who cannot must into battle with a blunted sword, so that their rage might harm none but themselves.

415.speaker: Player
415.text: You're a true warrior, Minsc - you don't need a petty thing like weapons.

81.speaker: Minsc
81.text: But still - I will strive to be worthy of this faith you show in me. After all - even a blunt blade can break some bones, is it not so?
81.context: NodeContext: Picking himself up - motivated by our faith in him. Rousing by end.

442.speaker: Minsc
442.text: Boo and I, we thank you for your kind words, my friend. But Minsc knows when he has made a mess that is for him, and him alone to clean.
442.context: NodeContext: Quiet, warm, appreciates us trying

179.speaker: Minsc
179.text: Fear not - this blunt blade will be whetted once more, on as many culty butts as he can reach!
179.context: NodeContext: As fierce and solemn a vow as he an make.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: Ah, excellent! Our heroic epic needs a moment of doubt - before your inevitable victory.

340.speaker: Player
340.text: From what little I know, you've survived worse. I think the gods must be watching over you.

414.speaker: Player
414.text: So be like Boo, and fight with the weapons nature gave you.

271.speaker: Player
271.text: Well, it's only fair to give your enemies a tactical advantage. I don't think it will save them, though.

230.speaker: Player
230.text: With a spirit like yours, you don't need a weapon - you are one.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: You're still fighting for your cause, a century after you began. Don't doubt yourself now.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: You're a survivor. I'd wager you've taken down fiercer quarry with less than a blunted sword.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: If you forget who we're fighting, my blade can give you a little jab in the right direction.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: My power has hurt friends as well as enemies, too. I'll make sure you don't forget which is which.

363.speaker: Player
363.text: Honestly, the thought of you with a blunt sword is no less frightening.

531.speaker: Player
531.text: You have power - and you decided how to use it. No one else.

350.speaker: Player
350.text: That's a good idea. Maybe we should just take all sharp objects away from you altogether.

100.speaker: Minsc
100.text: Eh... it is a sword of symbols only, my friend. Obviously, no one will be taking Minsc's weapons from him, lest they plan to strip him of his boots, too.
100.context: NodeContext: Speaking to us like we're a little dumb - sorry about what he did, but not THAT sorry

280.speaker: Player
280.text: I would never make you do that, Minsc. That's barbaric.

261.speaker: Minsc
261.text: It is anything but, my friend, because none can make a berserker do aught they do not wish, no more than Minsc can bathe Boo when he's feeling wrigglesome.
261.context: NodeContext: Not annoyed, but serene and serious about his home's custom - they hold themselves to a standard.

131.speaker: Minsc
131.text: Besides - you are aware that this is a thing of metaphor, yes? Minsc will not actually be surrendering his sword.
131.context: NodeContext: Leaning in to whisper, as if trying to spare our dumb ass a little embarrassment.

305.speaker: Player
305.text: I don't think you're half as dumb as you pretend.

304.speaker: Minsc
304.text: Minsc pretends at nothing, half the way or otherwise!

130.speaker: Minsc
130.text: There is more than a little to know, I think. I am huge.

468.speaker: Minsc
468.text: Minsc is an open book, with many pretty pictures.

390.speaker: Player
390.text: We haven't known each other long - but I think I would like to be more than friends.

373.speaker: Minsc
373.text: My friend...? You saved my oldest and best and oldest friend from the shadow lands.

343.speaker: Minsc
343.text: You pulled Minsc from the Absolute's hateful hands, and delivered him back into those of his hamster.

464.speaker: Minsc
464.text: You chased after me, time and again, and saved me when you did not even know me - we are already 'more than friends'.

334.speaker: Minsc
334.text: We are the best of friends! Comrades in arms! Companions in common cause! This is what you mean?

338.speaker: Minsc
338.text: Ah. You dart from one thing to another like Boo when he has supped on sugar. But I am glad you have raised this matter, for it has much been on the mind of Minsc also.

155.speaker: Minsc
155.text: No sex is an excellent idea.

366.speaker: Minsc
366.text: Minsc is not the den mother, to deny his campmates their under-the-blankets business. But rest is important, and all our sweaty strength might be best directed at the cult.

168.speaker: Minsc
168.text: Or, at the very least, taken far outside of my hamster's hearing. I will say no more on the matter.

465.speaker: Player
465.text: I had hoped we had grown a little closer than that.

527.speaker: Minsc
527.text: Closer? Hah! You could only be closer if you were to wriggle beneath my blankets with Boo!

231.speaker: Minsc
231.text: And he is a little protective of his territory, eh? Minsc thinks you will sleep more soundly in your own bed.

247.speaker: Minsc
247.text: And, if Minsc may be so bold - none of this funny under-the-covers business with any of our fellows. We must save our sweaty strength for the Absolute, eh?

141.speaker: Player
141.text: I refuse to believe that you are this dumb.

419.speaker: Minsc
419.text: Aw. Do you see? This is the manner of compliment that only good friends pay to one another!

368.speaker: Minsc
368.text: As thanks, Minsc shall take first watch when we sleep this night! Rest well, my friend.

514.speaker: Player
514.text: You've told me about Rashemen - but why did you leave?

8.speaker: Minsc
8.text: Oh, my friend - there is much more to know of Minsc's homeland than he could ever put into words. Boo might fare better, but his home is far stranger again.

425.speaker: Minsc
425.text: Well. In many ways, it is the very opposite of this city. The far side of Faerûn, with empty plains, white forests, and peaks that pierce the very belly of the sky!

409.speaker: Minsc
409.text: But it is like the city too. Here, it is loud with the daily wailing of people. In Rashemen, it is also loud - if you know where to listen.

446.speaker: Minsc
446.text: The telthors: guardian spirits of every root, rock, and tree. Here in the Sleeping Lands they are silent - but in the far north, they know how to speak still.

470.speaker: Player
470.text: It sounds like an amazing place. Why did you ever leave?

325.speaker: Player
325.text: So plants and trees speak to you. Like your hamster.

137.speaker: Minsc
137.text: Such a sceptic, my friend! Minsc cannot prove the point to you, for the telthors of this land lie sleeping - and for this, we had best be glad.

232.speaker: Minsc
232.text: In Rashemen, a telthor is wind and snow and soil. In Baldur's Gate, it would be stink and stain and... a far less pleasant type of soil.
232.context: NodeContext: Vibrant, proud of his homeland - into a little nose-wrinkling at the surrounds of Baldur's Gate

433.speaker: Minsc
433.text: If my meaning is not clear... just check under your boot.
433.context: NodeContext: Referencing the probable shit on our shoes.

515.speaker: Player
515.text: Rashemen sounds like an interesting place. Why did you leave?

469.speaker: Minsc
469.text: The first time - my dajemma. A warrior's quest of proving. Minsc quickly proved that quests do not always go as the stories say.

160.speaker: Minsc
160.text: As you know, he stumbled at the first step... protecting his witch.

395.speaker: Minsc
395.text: After wandering a ways, and some savings of the Sword Coast, Minsc returned to Rashemen. To find a welcome fit for hamsters and heroes!

297.speaker: Minsc
297.text: The Iron Lord himself came to bear witness to Boo. 'Minsc of Rashemen,' said he. 'Your dajemma is done.'

378.speaker: Minsc
378.text: Minsc politely disagreed. Dynaheir was dead, and so his dajemma could never be done.

113.speaker: Minsc
113.text: 'Then swear your service to me, Minsc of Rashemen,' said he. 'Serve your land as your lord's chosen champion!'

288.speaker: Minsc
288.text: Minsc politely disagreed. It was a little awkward, but he had already sworn his service to Boo.

37.speaker: Minsc
37.text: 'Minsc of Rashemen!' said he. 'You insult your Iron Lord - we will settle this matter in the circle of combat!'

418.speaker: Minsc
418.text: It was only polite for Minsc to agree.

528.speaker: Minsc
528.text: After they carried the Iron Lord away, the council of witches gave Minsc a pack of provisions, and said it would be best if he continued his adventures for a time.

250.speaker: Minsc
250.text: Yes, Boo... that was before we were stone. Perhaps we are due a little homecoming when all of this is done, no?

410.speaker: Minsc
410.text: As you wish. Boo? Do you have much to say on the matter of 'something else'?

307.speaker: Player
307.text: Why do you call this the Sleeping Lands?

0.speaker: Minsc
0.text: Because it is slow and stupid and sleeping. Ah - Boo says Minsc should phrase this in a kinder fashion.
0.context: NodeContext: First sentence a shrug, as if it's obvious. Then Boo interjects

267.speaker: Minsc
267.text: Telthors are the living soul of the land. They flit about, offering petty blessings to those who show respect, or playing tricks on those who do not.

500.speaker: Minsc
500.text: This is so in Rashemen - but not beyond her borders. Here, the spirits sleep - and perhaps we ought to be glad of this.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: Have you and Jaheira always had such a quarrelsome relationship?

98.speaker: Minsc
98.text: We have! Is it not wonderful?

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Do you even know what 'quarrelsome' means...?

172.speaker: Minsc
172.text: To irk your friend so that she wishes to fill you with some crossbow quarrels - but knowing she never will, for fear of hitting your hamster.

199.speaker: Minsc
199.text: There is no need for sweet words between companions such as we. Too often those are the weapons of flatterers, and frauds.

89.speaker: Minsc
89.text: But she who will beat you about the head with the cold and pointy truth? That is a true wychlaran.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: For such a sacred title, you hand it out pretty freely. First Dynaheir, now Jaheira.

462.speaker: Minsc
462.text: You suggest that Minsc uses the term lightly? Simply leaps from Dynaheir to Jaheira, with no caring for the custom itself? An unworthy thought - and WRONG!

243.speaker: Minsc
243.text: In between there was also Aerie, my second witch.

103.speaker: Minsc
103.text: She needed a protector, and Boo suggested that it might as well be Minsc. And when she went her own way, Minsc and Boo set to thinking:

406.speaker: Minsc
406.text: There is power in the wychlaran bond. Far too much to be wasted on weeping. To use that power to serve the living does not sully the dead - it honours them.

473.speaker: Minsc
473.text: You do not know this custom? Great Rashemen is ruled by the Masked Ones - wise women you might call 'witches'.

426.speaker: Minsc
426.text: To each wychlaran is bonded a berserker bodyguard. To dog her heels and watch her back, until death claims one or both.

516.speaker: Minsc
516.text: So it was with Minsc and his witch, Dynaheir. Until she died, and Minsc had to carry on without her.

312.speaker: Minsc
312.text: But Jaheira was there - to help Minsc take vengeance, and to kick his backside when he fell to brooding. As any true wychlaran would.

367.speaker: Player
367.text: So, what? One witch dies and you immediately pick another?

486.speaker: Player
486.text: That's nothing to do with being a wychlaran - it's just called being a friend.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: It's sweet that you still have each other after all this time.

529.speaker: Player
529.text: You clearly care for one another - so enough of the arguing.

233.speaker: Player
233.text: Of course. That's nothing to do with the wychlaran bond - it's just being a friend.

481.speaker: Minsc
481.text: Hm. So... duty, camaraderie, help in troubled times - what I call the bond of a wychlaran, you simply call... friendship?

450.speaker: Minsc
450.text: I think I understand your meaning. Then Jaheira is my wychlaran - and so are you. You are my wychlaran!

11.speaker: Minsc
11.text: And Karlach is my wychlaran! Or - no, Karlach is a berserker, so... perhaps Minsc is her wychlaran?

45.speaker: Minsc
45.text: My thanks to you, wychlaran. You have given me much to think on - and should some enemy blow knock it loose again, Boo shall remind me.

407.speaker: Minsc
407.text: And Minthara is - eh. A friend of yours, I am sure.

510.speaker: Player
510.text: I think you're just describing a friend.

526.speaker: Player
526.text: It's sweet that you and Jaheira still have one another after all this time.

173.speaker: Minsc
173.text: A hero is only as good the friends they have at their back.

412.speaker: Minsc
412.text: This is why Boo favours the spot just above my buttocks.

497.speaker: Player
497.text: You clearly care for one another - so enough of the arguing.

405.speaker: Minsc
405.text: ...I know you mean well, my friend. But Boo, being your friend, wishes to share some of this cold and pointy truth I mention.

43.speaker: Minsc
43.text: 'Mind your own godsdamned business.' My hamster's words, not mine!

509.speaker: Jaheira
509.text: And I am in total agreement. See? No arguing.

327.speaker: Player
327.text: She risked a lot to save you. She cares, whatever she says.

432.speaker: Player
432.text: I just need to know you're going to listen to her from now on. To me.

176.speaker: Minsc
176.text: Of course! Minsc always listens to Jaheira, even if Boo must sometimes explain her meaning afterwards.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Answer me honestly - what's with the hamster?

318.speaker: Minsc
318.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minsc looks down at his armour - Boo is nestled somewhere within, unseen.NodeContext: Minsc looks down at his armour. The hamster is nestled somewhere within. Unseen. Extended squeak from Boo explaining himself in answer to Minsc's line.

147.speaker: Minsc
147.text: Boo has a way with words that we lack. All that space in the cheeks, I am thinking.

376.speaker: Player
376.text: I speak with animals - why can't I understand him?

460.speaker: Minsc
460.text: Can you not? Do you not see his noble bearing? The deep wells of wisdom that are his eyes?
460.context: CinematicNodeContext: Boo in idle, very-much-a-hamster pose.

404.speaker: Minsc
404.text: Boo speaks of much - perhaps, one day, you will be ready to listen.

459.speaker: Player
459.text: Enough joking. Does the hamster actually speak to you?

229.speaker: Minsc
229.text: There is nothing jestful in the bond between a ranger and his companion.

336.speaker: Minsc
336.text: Before Boo, I was a typical berserker of Rashemen. Duty-bound, and full of my own seriousness.

483.speaker: Minsc
483.text: The problem with one so gazing of their navel, however - they are easily ambushed. Brigands split my skull like a sodden wine-skin.

303.speaker: Minsc
303.text: It was as I recovered that Boo first appeared. He told me that I had felt the great poking finger of justice - marking Minsc as its champion and Boo as my guide!

302.speaker: Minsc
302.text: As for the headache, well - justice cannot always afford to be gentle.

228.speaker: Player
228.text: So you're a paladin of justice?

287.speaker: Minsc
287.text: If any of us is chosen by the gods, it is obviously Boo.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: You lost your mind and gained a rat. Understood.

108.speaker: Minsc
108.text: Bah. The way you tell the tale, it sounds almost silly.

430.speaker: Player
430.text: Maybe someday you'll trust me enough to tell the real tale.

224.speaker: Minsc
224.text: Real...? Boo, I think our friend has suffered a head-wound of their own.

203.speaker: Minsc
203.text: Now, shall we away? My boots crave the crunch of unvirtuous nethers.

181.speaker: Player
181.text: There is something very wrong with you.

394.speaker: Minsc
394.text: Ahh! You speak of Minsc's misshapen skull? It is true, I once suffered a most heroic head-wound.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Jaheira said you spent a century as a statue on the Wide. I'd like to hear about it.

439.speaker: Minsc
439.text: Ahh, you come in search of stories? It is not yet time to tuck Boo in for the night - but very well!

174.speaker: Minsc
174.text: After our adventurings with the Bhaalspawn, Boo had had his fill of godly flesh. So we returned to Baldur's Gate for a time.

211.speaker: Minsc
211.text: After all - in every city there is a sweaty underbelly, crying out for a virtuous scrubbing. None better to wield the brush than Minsc and Boo!

150.speaker: Minsc
150.text: Perhaps we rubbed some villain's rump a little too raw - this, Minsc does not know. One moment, we stood in the city's slums.

74.speaker: Minsc
74.text: The next - ambush! Then Minsc and Boo woke on the Wide, with stone-dust in... sensitive places.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: So that's how you became known as the Stone Lord.

502.speaker: Minsc
502.text: Aha! Perhaps this is the reason, Boo. It is not because of the legendary thickness of my skull.

283.speaker: Player
283.text: And you never saw who did it?

487.speaker: Minsc
487.text: The mind of Minsc was occupied with important matters. I was browsing at a slum vendor's stall, looking for Boo's favourite nuts.

503.speaker: Player
503.text: What was it like being a statue?

385.speaker: Minsc
385.text: If you wish to know the answer to that, ask a statue.

87.speaker: Minsc
87.text: For Minsc, those years passed as quick as a hiccup. It was long ago, then - hick! - it is now.
87.context: NodeContext: [Ruairí here: annoyingly requesting a retake on this, as Matt previously used a hiccup sound and it was much funnier - but that was recorded over by accident.]

420.speaker: Player
420.text: You travelled a hundred years in a moment - what do you make of this new world?

35.speaker: Minsc
35.text: I do not like these metal men on the streets, or the villains who hide behind them. But the new world is not so different to the old one.

375.speaker: Minsc
375.text: The city still clings to the hill, the sea still stretches on forever. And the stench of evil still makes Boo wish for a tiny peg on his nose.

524.speaker: Minsc
524.text: As long as that stench remains, no matter how old or young the world is, Minsc and Boo will not rest.

476.speaker: Player
476.text: You inspired people even as a statue.

427.speaker: Minsc
427.text: Jaheira says Minsc and Boo were often draped in flowers, and showered with wine. Still as stone, but the life of the party nonetheless!

504.speaker: Minsc
504.text: But there is no glory without action, and no valour without violence!

328.speaker: Minsc
328.text: I would rather be as small as Boo, yet made of muscle and rage and virtue, than as large as Minsc but made of cold stone.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: So much that you cared for must have been lost while you were petrified.

252.speaker: Minsc
252.text: Minsc has lost many things - his witch, his mind, his home, his friends, his mind - but many good things remain.

429.speaker: Minsc
429.text: Boo is here. My steel is here. Jaheira's face has more lines, but her tongue and wits are as sharp as ever.

466.speaker: Player
466.text: You travelled with Bhaalspawn before, didn't you? What do you know of them?

114.speaker: Minsc
114.text: Ahh, Boo has an inkling that this is not the question you mean to ask. I saw some hint of things when our minds mushed together - but Jaheira confirmed it for me.

475.speaker: Minsc
475.text: You are of the same blood as our old friend: a Bhaalspawn, and as close to Minsc as if they were his own kin.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: That's all you have to say? You're not worried what my blood might turn me into?

342.speaker: Player
342.text: I'm not sure I'm ready to call you uncle.

86.speaker: Minsc
86.text: So long as you do not call Bhaal 'Father Dearest', you may call Minsc whatever you wish. Family is a complicated knot, big as a fist!

193.speaker: Player
193.text: What manner of relation does that make Boo?

294.speaker: Minsc
294.text: Better not to ask. He has many dozen cousins, and not all are so open-minded about we who walk on our hind legs as he.

477.speaker: Minsc
477.text: There is a lesson in this. We are born into a bloodline, yes - but we need not be bound by it.

320.speaker: Player
320.text: You travelled with a Bhaalspawn. How did you come to trust the child of an evil god?

496.speaker: Player
496.text: All you told me about the old days: you seem so positive for someone who's lost so much.

161.speaker: Player
161.text: Is it true you travelled with the Bhaalspawn who saved Baldur's Gate?

139.speaker: Minsc
139.text: Countless tales are told of Boo and Minsc. Many of them are so outlandish that even I do not know if they are true!

339.speaker: Minsc
339.text: Did Minsc bravely fend off the seductive wiles of a succubus in the cloisters of Candlekeep? Maybe.

492.speaker: Minsc
492.text: Did he take a bath in the River Styx and temporarily forget himself? I do not remember.

508.speaker: Minsc
508.text: Did he travel with a spawn of the god of murder, who warred against his evil brethren, and battled triumphantly at the Throne of Bhaal itself?

382.speaker: Minsc
382.text: Of course. It was a splendid adventure.

451.speaker: Player
451.text: How did you come to trust the spawn of such an evil god?

263.speaker: Minsc
263.text: A curious question. Are a child and his father always alike?

317.speaker: Minsc
317.text: Take Minsc! He does not have a clear memory of the face of his father, but he does remember tugging on the thick, red whiskers that sprang from his chin.

202.speaker: Minsc
202.text: A beard for the ages! Boo could have nested there happily through even the harshest of Rashemen winters.

351.speaker: Minsc
351.text: Now - look closely at Minsc, and what do you see?

413.speaker: Minsc
413.text: Correct! There are more whiskers on Boo's tiny face than on the mighty chin of Minsc!
413.context: NodeContext: Boo squeaks before Minsc's line

39.speaker: Minsc
39.text: Boo is correct. No beard! There are more whiskers on his tiny face than on the mighty chin of Minsc!
39.context: NodeContext: Boo squeaks before Minsc's line

246.speaker: Minsc
246.text: If Minsc did not inherit the flaming red hair of his mother, or the bushy red beard of his father, why would the spawn of Bhaal inherit his wickedness?

49.speaker: Player
49.text: And if I want to be more like my father?

31.speaker: Minsc
31.text: In a moment of madness, Minsc might want to sprout a bushy red beard. But he trusts his friends will be there, to speak to his better nature.

33.speaker: Minsc
33.text: And failing that - to end his madness with the cleansing blade.

501.speaker: Player
501.text: Thank you. It's nice not having to justify myself for once.

120.speaker: Minsc
120.text: Minsc is not here to judge - that is a thing for hamsters and hathrans alone.

162.speaker: Minsc
162.text: I have many more thoughts about beards to share. I did not know you cared to hear them!

40.speaker: Player
40.text: We should talk about nature versus nurture some day.

322.speaker: Minsc
322.text: It is simple. As with all battles, the winner will be the one that carries the bigger sword.

265.speaker: Player
265.text: This is nonsense, Minsc. Evil isn't like a beard.

48.speaker: Minsc
48.text: It is precisely the same! Although one is far easier to kick than the other.

443.speaker: Minsc
443.text: Your gaze is naturally caught on my handsome face - the face that is loved by all - but cast your eyes down. Just a little. Not so far as to make Minsc blush.

194.speaker: Minsc
194.context: CinematicNodeContext: looking over his shoulders, suspecting someone is standing behind himNodeContext: looking over his shoulders, suspecting someone is behind him

4.speaker: Minsc
4.text: Do not speak ill of our friends, and please, focus your gaze on Minsc.

423.speaker: Player
423.text: What is your fondest memory of adventuring with Bhaalspawn?

277.speaker: Minsc
277.text: The bards sing of fallen gods and mighty battles, but that is a small part of any saga.

537.speaker: Minsc
537.text: They do not sing of the times in between.

484.speaker: Minsc
484.text: When Sarevok's butt had been kicked so hard that we thought he would never return, we settled in Baldur's Gate for a while.

65.speaker: Minsc
65.text: Gorion's Ward, Imoen, Jaheira, Minsc, Boo... and Dynaheir. My witch.

28.speaker: Minsc
28.text: She hated the city at first. Too busy, she said, too noisy. Too many people.
28.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing about a story that's about to turn tragic

335.speaker: Minsc
335.text: She complained of the smell, although she complained of Boo's smell too and he smells of fresh honeycakes, so Minsc believes her nose was confused.

187.speaker: Minsc
187.text: Then, one day, we walked past a shop full of wonders. Tiny magics fizzed in the air, and wizards from every corner of the world bickered and bartered.
187.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

530.speaker: Minsc
530.text: Sorcerous Sundries. Dynaheir fell in love. Dragged poor Minsc there every day, and made him stand watch while she browsed the shelves.
530.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

101.speaker: Minsc
101.text: Minsc frowned and complained. He felt more like a babysitter than a berserker.
101.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

347.speaker: Minsc
347.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

522.speaker: Minsc
522.text: Not long after, Minsc and Boo were captured, and Dynaheir was dead.
522.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

157.speaker: Minsc
157.text: I would gladly be a babysitter again, to see her smile.
157.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

488.speaker: Minsc
488.text: That is what I remember, more than any battles against Bhaal and his spawn.
488.context: NodeContext: fondly reminiscing - lower volume than usual

209.speaker: Minsc
209.text: Yes, Boo. I know you miss her too.
209.context: NodeContext: Gentle comforting squeak from Boo before Minsc's line.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: You seem so positive for someone who has lost so much.

314.speaker: Minsc
314.text: Boo says the tadpole thrives on our misery - to think dark thoughts is only to feed the darkness.

298.speaker: Minsc
298.text: It pleases Minsc more to sour its stomach with good thoughts - or better yet, not to think at all!

72.speaker: Minsc
72.text: With this in mind - Minsc thinks he has gathered enough fluff from gazing at his navel for the moment, no?
72.context: NodeContext: Cheerfully, but firmly, moving onto other topics.

478.speaker: Player
478.text: I'd like to know your thoughts on our companions.

270.speaker: Minsc
270.text: Boo is ready with the musings.

332.speaker: Minsc
332.text: You hear that, Boo? Your keen skills of observation have not gone unnoticed! Our friend wishes to consult your wisdom.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: Actually, it really was your opinions I wanted. Not the hamster's.

212.speaker: Minsc
212.text: Minsc and Boo are of one mind, and one heart. And Boo is the wiser.

70.speaker: Minsc
70.text: So small is Boo that he is often mistaken for a pinecone, and many secrets are spoken in his hearing! He will tell what he knows.

499.speaker: Minsc
499.text: But Minsc, of course, will translate.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Let's hear your thoughts on Astarion.

424.speaker: Minsc
424.text: Eh, Boo has said it is unkind to speak behind the backs of some of our companions.

127.speaker: Minsc
127.text: And unwise to say certain things to their faces.

329.speaker: Minsc
329.text: Oh, the pale scoundrel has his charms, it cannot be denied. But, my friend, it gives me no pleasure to tell you - Astarion is not what he claims to be.

472.speaker: Minsc
472.text: Just last night, Minsc was dressing one of his many heroic wounds in camp - when Astarion stumbled upon the scene.

408.speaker: Minsc
408.text: I tell you, he grew pale as death itself. He licked his lips, and trembled so violently that Minsc thought he might faint on the spot!

353.speaker: Minsc
353.text: The truth is painful, but undeniable. Astarion... is a coward. How can he fight the battles to come, when he grows soft at the first sight of blood?

226.speaker: Minsc
226.context: NodeContext: Boo squeaks an explanation before Minsc's line - that Astarion is a vampire

1.speaker: Minsc
1.text: You are sure? And you could not have told me this before?
1.context: NodeContext: Boo continues a squeaking explanation

2.speaker: Minsc
2.text: Minsc may have been mistaken. Boo presents compelling evidence that Astarion may in fact be a vampire.
2.context: NodeContext: talking to player - annoyed with Boo, who just let you make a fool of yourself

44.speaker: Player
44.text: That he is. But one of the good ones.

136.speaker: Minsc
136.text: Minsc has met many vampires, and never one whose smile did not hide treacherous teeth. But... as you say.

198.speaker: Minsc
198.text: This world is a strange and wondrous place. Minsc has seen the soul of an angel in a child of Bhaal. Once, even a kind banker.

164.speaker: Minsc
164.text: I fear my hamster has the right of it, as always. But fear not.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: I know. But don't worry - he largely gets by on rats.

77.speaker: Minsc
77.text: It is good that we do not have any friends who could ever be mistaken for a rat, eh, Boo?
77.context: NodeContext: Not sarcastic. He earnestly believes Boo could never be mistaken for a rat. End with worried squeaking from Boo.

163.speaker: Minsc
163.text: If the sun can bear to look upon Astarion's monstrous face, then so can Minsc and Boo! For now, at least.

521.speaker: Player
521.text: I'd like to hear your take on someone else.

259.speaker: Minsc
259.text: Ah, the great Blade of Frontiers! A fine name - Minsc has no idea what it means, but it suits young Wyll's air of mystery well.

152.speaker: Minsc
152.text: It is good to know the city did not go unprotected while I wore pigeon droppings on the Wide.

533.speaker: Minsc
533.text: Jaheira did her part, of course, but she prefers to scowl from the shadows. The city needs a name - a face! Preferably, a furry companion too.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: He has a companion, all right - her name is Mizora.

14.speaker: Minsc
14.text: Mizora. This is... some manner of exotic bird?

268.speaker: Player
268.text: Close. A cambion, bound to him by an infernal pact.

78.speaker: Minsc
78.text: What?! Wyll - the Blade of Frontiers of whom I heard - is no man to deal with devils.

480.speaker: Minsc
480.text: Boo speaks sense, as ever. There is goodness in Wyll - we have seen it.
480.context: NodeContext: Boo squeaks up in Wyll's defence before Minsc's line.

144.speaker: Minsc
144.text: If there be a devil on his shoulder, then Minsc and Boo will sit astride the other! He will not be long in coming back to himself, I think.

489.speaker: Player
489.text: I'll let him tell you himself.

32.speaker: Minsc
32.text: 'Mizora'. Perhaps she and Boo will be friends.
32.context: NodeContext: Thoughtful, trying out the name.

276.speaker: Player
276.text: Perhaps you and Wyll can team up, when all of this is over.

361.speaker: Minsc
361.text: Ohoho! Minsc would need a title to match - something to wash away the Stone Lord's stain.

444.speaker: Minsc
444.text: The Boot of Backsides, perhaps? Or -

370.speaker: Minsc
370.text: Ai, Boo! Evocative, but so crude. I will stick to simple Minsc.

435.speaker: Player
435.text: You can admit it. You're not a little bit jealous of his legend?

5.speaker: Minsc
5.text: What need for jealousy? Villainy's backside is ample and vast.

352.speaker: Minsc
352.text: There is room for us all - biting fleas astride the great buttocks of evil!

197.speaker: Player
197.text: You and Karlach must have a lot in common.

398.speaker: Minsc
398.text: Indeed! A berserker after my own heart. Though hers is made of hellish heat, and metal, and... some manner of coin-operated device?

506.speaker: Minsc
506.text: I... do not think so? Minsc has always been Minsc, except for the times he was stone or Stone Lord.

333.speaker: Minsc
333.text: Just as Karlach has always been Karlach. Even if all her parts were traded for tin and scrap, Minsc thinks this would still be so.

371.speaker: Player
371.text: Don't mock, Minsc. It's killing her.

52.speaker: Minsc
52.text: I would never think to mock! She is as fine a warrior as any I've met - Mazzy Fentan stretched two spans tall!

177.speaker: Minsc
177.text: No, better - Karlach is Karlach. Even if all her parts were traded for tin and scrap, Minsc thinks this would still be so.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: Gortash sold her to Zariel. He has a lot to answer for.

289.speaker: Minsc
289.text: That he does! And all of the questions that Minsc has to ask are of the pointed and painful kind.

24.speaker: Minsc
24.text: But for all his betrayings of Karlach, Gortash never for a moment bested her.

82.speaker: Minsc
82.text: Karlach remains Karlach. Even if all of her parts were traded for tin and scrap, Minsc thinks this would still be so.

121.speaker: Minsc
121.text: And soon, Karlach will still be Karlach, but Karlach will also be cured.

190.speaker: Minsc
190.text: Minsc knows he is right, because Boo is in agreement - and hamsters have no need of hope.

319.speaker: Player
319.text: You need to prepare yourself for the possibility that she won't make it.

215.speaker: Minsc
215.text: And if she dies, what of it, says Boo? The Hells themselves could not hold the first time - and now she knows the way back.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: You should tell Karlach you think so highly of her.

57.speaker: Minsc
57.text: Bah! She knows - a warrior always knows. After all, do you not see the wicked gleam of wisdom in Minsc and Boo's own eyes?

482.speaker: Player
482.text: Gortash sold her to Zariel. He had a lot to answer for.

453.speaker: Minsc
453.text: Hah - well, may he answer to the archdevil herself, and may all her questions be hot pokers pressed against his flesh!

25.speaker: Player
25.text: How are you and Gale getting along?

387.speaker: Minsc
387.text: I do not wish to speak of the wizard.

295.speaker: Minsc
295.text: I could not have said it better myself.
295.context: NodeContext: Annoyed squeak from Boo before Minsc's line, complaining about Gale.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Gale's great - what's your problem with him?

42.speaker: Minsc
42.text: He came to me one night with a little book of mischief - full of words and their meanings.

345.speaker: Minsc
345.text: 'Posterior', he says. 'Can you say 'posterior'?' I refused! Minsc does not need to know the language of wizards.

200.speaker: Player
200.text: 'Posterior' isn't wizard-talk - it's another word for 'butt'.

105.speaker: Minsc
105.text: It is an inferior word. Far too long to use in a battle cry, which is where a 'butt' belongs.

357.speaker: Minsc
357.text: Gale would do better to educate himself in the ways of sword and steel than to throw these pointy words at Minsc.

135.speaker: Minsc
135.text: Ai, yes. Gale also owns a cat. A cat with wings! That is most unnerving for poor Boo.
135.context: NodeContext: Indignant squeak from Boo before Minsc line.

493.speaker: Player
493.text: You should give him a break - he's only trying to help.

392.speaker: Minsc
392.text: Never! If he is not careful, Boo will shred his books and use them as bedding!

281.speaker: Player
281.text: Did you know that he has an explosive magical orb in his chest that could destroy a city?

220.speaker: Minsc
220.text: That is a thousand times more interesting than anything that has ever been written in a book.

498.speaker: Minsc
498.text: GALE! MY GOOD FRIEND! WHERE ARE YOU? MINSC AND BOO WOULD LIKE TO HEAR ABOUT THE EXPLODING.

310.speaker: Player
310.text: You're right - he is very annoying.

175.speaker: Minsc
175.text: Wizards are either annoying, boring, or evil. The worst ones are all three things at the same time!

192.speaker: Player
192.text: He was trying to teach you a mighty spell!

245.speaker: Minsc
245.text: An impossible task! Minsc knows everything that Minsc knows, and Boo knows the rest.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: He was trying to educate you - no harm in that.

379.speaker: Player
379.text: What did he do to upset you?

146.speaker: Player
146.text: I get it - Gale annoys the hell out of me as well.

99.speaker: Minsc
99.text: Even Boo finds him irritating, and Boo is the most patient soul in the Realms!

479.speaker: Minsc
479.text: Oh, the tiny puny elf with leaves in his hair, and dirt under his fingernails.

356.speaker: Minsc
356.text: His name is Halitosin? How very unfortunate.

440.speaker: Player
440.text: You're both giant, hulking do-gooders. I thought you'd get along.

94.speaker: Minsc
94.text: Pah! Minsc saw the druid chasing himself in circles, and sniffing his own butt last night. He has spent too long as a wolf, and not enough as a man!

69.speaker: Minsc
69.text: He is so small that Minsc barely notices his existence.

241.speaker: Minsc
241.text: NO, BOO! THE DRUID DID NOT BEAT MINSC AT THE ARM-WRESTLING!
241.context: NodeContext: Boo squeaks up before Minsc's line, indignant at his fibbing.

221.speaker: Minsc
221.text: IT WAS NOT A FAIR MATCH, AND HE TURNED INTO AN OWLBEAR MIDWAY THROUGH, AND THERE WAS GREASE ON THE TREE STUMP!

437.speaker: Minsc
437.text: Somehow such a person as you describe has entirely escaped Minsc's notice. How strange.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: Seriously? The druid - he's hard to miss.

401.speaker: Player
401.text: You'll like him - he reminds me of you a little.

441.speaker: Minsc
441.text: If such a tiny puny druid-man reminds you of Minsc, I think the tadpole may have made a feast of your brain!

225.speaker: Player
225.text: What do you make of Minthara?

196.speaker: Minsc
196.text: Ah. Well. You have travelled at her side much longer than Minsc and Boo. What is it you feel for her?
196.context: NodeContext: Sheepish - we've asked him his opinion on Minthara, who he dislikes, but is quite possibly our lover.

60.speaker: Minsc
60.text: Much like baby Minsc loved running head-first into rocks, I'd wager. Dizzying fun - until you are left bawling on your back.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: Minthara has made a fine playmate.

186.speaker: Minsc
186.text: Ugh. Please do not speak this way. I just felt Boo roll up into a ball.

53.speaker: Minsc
53.text: OhpraisetheThree. So, I will speak freely.

471.speaker: Minsc
471.text: Of the drow I can say only this - she may be treacherous, vicious, and much meaner than she has any need to be. But she is clearly no cleverer than Minsc.

365.speaker: Minsc
365.text: She too was duped by the Absolute - and she too seeks vengeance. So long as that is so, Minsc will not judge her.

123.speaker: Minsc
123.text: Aha! So there is business? Boo has nose for these things, you know. Best to, eh, double your bathing if you wish to deceive him.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: What do you think of Lae'zel?

227.speaker: Minsc
227.text: Minsc knows your people well. The skin of the world is thin up in Rashemen, and it is easier there for things to slip between the planes.

158.speaker: Minsc
158.text: Minsc knows her people well. The skin of the world is thin up in Rashemen, and it is easier there for things to slip between the planes.

309.speaker: Minsc
309.text: Sometimes these are wonders from other worlds. Sometimes warriors, hungry for plunder. Such visitors have inspired a saying among my people:

84.speaker: Minsc
84.text: 'The Children of Gith live long, and forget the face of death: and so they come to Rashemen to be reminded.'

447.speaker: Player
447.text: My people know of your berserkers, too. They make for fine and challenging prey.

494.speaker: Minsc
494.text: Hah, you think we are the prey? Our warriors only stopped hoarding your hides because they made for such poor leather.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: So you see the githyanki as your enemies?

106.speaker: Minsc
106.text: They are raiders, so they raid. Minsc's people are berserkers, and so they get a little grumpy at this. It is no bone-deep blood feud, as it is with the Red Wizards of Thay.
106.context: NodeContext: Shrugging - his people fight the githyanki with all their might, but he's offended by their raids.

237.speaker: Minsc
237.text: No, Minsc has no hatred for githyanki. It is a fine thing to fight against them - and a fine thing to fight beside them too, I think.

189.speaker: Minsc
189.text: Besides - the Children of Gith alone have witnessed a sight that I have long yearned to behold:

359.speaker: Narrator
359.text: *And for a moment, you share in a vision tinged with his awe: imaginings of the Astral Sea, an immense horde of wild space hamsters, drifting in the endless expanse.*

457.speaker: Minsc
457.text: The githyanki may have Minsc of Rashemen's ire; sometimes, healthy servings of his sword; but for this, and this alone, they shall always have his respect.

518.speaker: Player
518.text: Lae'zel is not her people. Nor am I.

391.speaker: Minsc
391.text: And Minsc did not mean to say so, no more than he is a hathran of his high country!

183.speaker: Player
183.text: She is a true githyanki - and our people have fought the illithids much longer than yours.

372.speaker: Minsc
372.text: Exactly so - and the illithids are our true enemies. If Boo must choose which enemy to fight - it will be fish eye he dines on first, not that of any githyanki.

208.speaker: Player
208.text: She's been a fine ally - and her people have fought the illithids much longer than we have.

143.speaker: Minsc
143.text: Minsc has already shared his thoughts on the githyanki. From what he can tell, Lae'zel is a fine githyanki.
143.context: NodeContext: Mirth - in this case, player is githyanki and Minsc has already described his people's clashes with githyanki raiders. 'Lae'zel is a fine githyanki' = could be compliment or slight dig.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: What are your thoughts on Shadowheart?

223.speaker: Minsc
223.text: She hangs split between her two sides - like a flipped coin that Boo once ate while it was still in the air.
223.context: NodeContext: As usual - starting out airy and philosophical, only to become very literal

313.speaker: Minsc
313.text: But, like Boo, after a great struggle within, I think Shadowheart has finally brought that coin to earth.

234.speaker: Minsc
234.text: She is a Sharran no more - and free of her wretched and evil fellows!

434.speaker: Player
434.text: I don't think all of the Sharrans were evil - some were just misguided.

381.speaker: Minsc
381.text: Boo says it was perhaps a den of denial rather than a den of evil. Minsc says one thing is very much like the other.

151.speaker: Minsc
151.text: Silence and secrecy grow evil just as a cellar grows mushrooms. Big, plump, stinking evil!

402.speaker: Minsc
402.text: That is why Minsc always speaks his mind. LOUDLY.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: Hard to believe Shadowheart grew up in that place.

159.speaker: Minsc
159.text: My old friend Keldorn told me that the righteous must end their rage when the battle is done.

195.speaker: Minsc
195.text: But when Minsc thinks of those villains tormenting our gentle moon-witch, he wants to kick them in the cloisters!

95.speaker: Minsc
95.text: Calm can not fight evil! Only Minsc can fight evil.

400.speaker: Minsc
400.text: But if Minsc can become calm, perhaps evil will learn to fear his serenity.

80.speaker: Minsc
80.text: Yes. It is working. Evil is unnerved by the righteous composure of Minsc!

170.speaker: Player
170.text: No need for rage - Shadowheart's safe now.

3.speaker: Minsc
3.text: Not just safe - she is among friends. Minsc is her friend, you are her friend, and most important of all, Boo is her friend.

374.speaker: Minsc
374.text: I do not know all of those words, but it is clear that Boo likes Shadowheart best of all.
374.context: NodeContext: Extended squeak from Boo before Minsc's line.

346.speaker: Minsc
346.text: A little too much, perhaps. It is good that Minsc is too reasonable to ever become jealous.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: We should burn their homes to the ground!

41.speaker: Minsc
41.text: YES! BURN, SAYS YOU AND BURN SAYS BOO! SO MINSC WILL BURN!

207.speaker: Minsc
207.text: WE SHALL SET FIRE TO THE NIGHT ITSELF!

34.speaker: Minsc
34.text: Or perhaps the night is too large to burn. I do not know. But I do know that I am angry.

50.speaker: Minsc
50.text: She has shown herself to be a true Sharran - and lost to all but Lady Loss herself!

204.speaker: Player
204.text: Shadowheart walks a dark path - but we can trust her.

337.speaker: Minsc
337.text: You are asking Minsc to be pragmatic. That is a word that Jaheira uses to win arguments.

107.speaker: Minsc
107.text: It does not work on Minsc because Minsc does not know what the word means.

467.speaker: Player
467.text: It's simple - the end justifies the means.

110.speaker: Minsc
110.text: If you are telling Minsc that it would be right to plant his boot on the hindquarters of a thousand tiny orphans in order to save the city...

58.speaker: Minsc
58.text: Minsc says you may not be as righteous as you believe yourself to be.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: It means that sometimes the enemy of your enemy is your friend.

257.speaker: Minsc
257.text: The enemy of my enemy is my sword and my boot. But the enemy of my enemy may also be my enemy, for evil often eats itself for supper.

260.speaker: Minsc
260.text: I still do not understand 'pragmatic'. But I believe you are a friend to Minsc and Boo. And an enemy to evil.

269.speaker: Player
269.text: I don't know what it means either.

239.speaker: Minsc
239.text: Then let us rely on swords, not words, my friend.

344.speaker: Minsc
344.text: And Boo shall watch Shadowheart like a tiny wingless hawk.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: I wish Shadowheart had chosen differently, but I'll stand by her.

118.speaker: Minsc
118.text: Boo has always stood by Minsc - even when Minsc made mistakes.

330.speaker: Minsc
330.text: But would Boo have stood by the Stone Lord? I do not think so.

126.speaker: Minsc
126.text: Be sure that your friend has not changed so much that she is no longer the person you knew.

23.speaker: Minsc
23.text: And in the meantime, Boo shall watch her like a tiny wingless hawk.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: We share an enemy right now, but... you're right. Shadowheart is evil.

97.speaker: Minsc
97.text: Then I do not understand why she shares your camp.

411.speaker: Minsc
411.text: Evil is my enemy - and I have two boots. One can stomp righteously on Sharran skulls while the other kicks the Absolute about the place.

46.speaker: Minsc
46.text: Boo says he believes that you are on the side of justice, but that the stink of Shar is not one easily washed out.

431.speaker: Minsc
431.text: Minsc says that you are perhaps not as righteous or sweet-smelling as you believe.

525.speaker: Minsc
525.text: We shall not know which side has won until it hits the earth, I think. So cough it up, Boo!
525.context: NodeContext: Shrug - serene about her struggle as it is her choice. But a little bit annoyed about the coin

358.speaker: Player
358.text: Yes, Boo. I'd love to hear your opinions.

474.speaker: Minsc
474.text: Not minding is one of the many things Minsc is known for!
